SWANning the Science Gender Gap

01/11/2014

A report in nature found that "Science remains institutionally sexist. Despite some progress, women scientists are still paid less, promoted less frequently, win fewer grants and are more likely to leave research than similarly qualified men." What is York doing to combat the gender gap?

Image by

By undefined undefined

As science students button up their lab coats and prepare for a new term of gruelling nine o'clock lectures, the news of 2014's Nobel Prize winners should come as welcome inspiration, especially for those suffering from a lack of motivation. Characterised by a prestige equivalent to that of the Oscars, the awards for Chemistry, Physics and Medicine are the subject of scientists' dreams the world-over. For female scientists, however, a glance at the list of past Laureates can make the chance of being awarded a Nobel seem just that; a dream. The Nobel Prizes were first awarded in 1901 following Alfred Nobel's dying request that his entire remaining estate be used to endow 'prizes to those who, during the preceding year, shall have conferred the greatest benefit on mankind'. Since then 566 Laureates have been awarded prizes for Physics, Chemistry and Medicine. Just 17 of these have been awarded to women. Historically, science was considered a male profession: any women involved were considered to be serving men and science, not as pioneers themselves. Mary Curie, the first person to win Nobel prizes in two separate disciplines, was turned down by the French Academy of Sciences in 1911 on the basis that she was a woman. Whilst such outright sexism wouldn't be tolerated in this day and age, women still are, consciously or unconsciously, discriminated against in science, engineering and technology. The US National Science Foundation found that, on average, women earn 82% of what men make. In another study where 127 professors from 6 different US universities were asked to evaluate two CVs, the professors said they would offer $3730 less per year to 'Jennifer' than to 'John' despite their CVs being identical. In recent years there have been various campaigns created, in an attempt to up-end this cultural sexism. Just in case the Nobel Laureates weren't inspiration enough to get you through your first month of labs, October 14th has been pronounced Ada Lovelace Day, 'an international day celebrating the achievements of women in science technology, engineering and maths'. Named after the first computer programmer, the day was set up after psychologist Penelope Lockwood emphasised the need for female role models. If that doesn't tickle your frontal lobe, there are always the Women in Science and Engineering (WISE) Awards to look forward to in November. WISE inspires young women to challenge science gender stereotypes through the promotion of role models, advertisement of funding for women and campaigning for equal opportunities for women to progress in scientific careers. This is all well and good, but is it actually making an impact? According to the Higher Education Statistics Agency, the percentage of girls taking Physical Science subjects at University in the UK has increased by just 7% over the past six years, from 35% to 42%. In Engineering, for which the ratio of male to female students is 5:1, is similar to Maths in that the percentage of women taking subjects in this area has increased by just 3.5%. The only science where girls appear to fare better is in the Biological Sciences, with the number of females outweighing males three to two. Jane Hill, Athena SWAN champion for the Biology department at York, believes that this is partly due to science students having the wrong perceptions about what they can achieve. In a recent interview with Soapbox Science for an event which aimed to promote women in science, she proposed that "mentorship should be better recognized as 'part of the job' of an academic/scientist, and provided for all scientists at every stage of their career, to help expand horizons and achieve them." This was after a survey within the department in 2013 showed that just 50% of female students thought that men and women had an equal chance of a successful career in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics). Another factor thought to be a major contributor to the gender gap in science is the perception that women have to choose between having a family or a successful career. Female scientists are most fertile at the time in their career when they feel they should be building their portfolio, not looking after babies. A study at the University of California, Berkeley, found that female post-doctorates who have or plan to have children end up abandoning research careers up to twice as often as men in similar circumstances. Another study carried out at the same university found that only one in three women who accepts a fast-track university job goes on to become a mother. In an attempt to change this, the University of York has adopted the Athena SWAN scheme in each of its STEM departments. The scheme encourages institutions to show sustained progression and achievement in promoting gender equality. York's Chemistry department received an Athena SWAN Gold award in 2007 - the first academic department in the UK to do so. The Department of Biology followed in its footsteps in 2013, making it the first Biology department in the country to achieve the standards of equality required. The flexibility and support promoted by the scheme has allowed for many women working within science departments at York to make choices they might otherwise not have been able to. For instance, the Chemistry department has achieved a 100% return rate from maternity leave. This allowed staff like Professor Lucy Carpenter and Dr Caroline Dessent to raise children whilst attaining senior roles in the department. With increasing support for the equality of women in science, there is a good chance that we will see more female Nobel Prize Laureates over the next decade or so. Investing in these schemes is important in overcoming the many hurdles we face in creating equality for men and women in science. Meanwhile, we should look to those who lecture us on a day-to-day basis for inspirational role models. With the support given by the university, our teaching staff are becoming the pioneering female scientists of the 21st century.
